results.title: The Passionate eye
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The influence of Napoleon on French art and architecture is examined. The Emperor encouraged the classical Roman style. The age of Romanticism is studied in which the direct expression of natural feeling is extolled above the control of intellect.

results.title: The Passion to play
results.creator_credit: Peter Dickson, Hush Productions International and Rob Dickson
results.brief_description: Sport has the power to unite and also to divide. It has the ability to build a person’s confidence and at the same time destroy another’s spirit. Australian Rules Football has for generations provided individuals and communities with a distraction from the normal focus of life. Created by our natural desire for competition, it has thrilled the masses, and for many, provided a way of life. It is the players that determine its power and this video is a celebration of those players. Players past and present, representing the 16 different clubs, discuss the game and their careers, providing insight into the journey of playing Australian Rules Football as a senior, the thrill of the first game and the heartache of being told your time is up.

results.title: The Passion of the Christ
results.creator_credit: ICON, Mel Gibson, Bruce Davey and Stephen McEveety
results.brief_description: Written (with Benedict Fitzgerald), directed and produced by Mel Gibson, “The Passion of the Christ” is the realisation of a very personal project for Gibson. The film deals with the last twelve hours of Jesus of Nazareth’s life opening in the Garden of Gethsemane. Betrayed by the disciple Judas, Jesus (Jim Caviezel) is arrested and stands accused of blasphemy before religious leaders, who insist he should be punished by death. Before the crucifixion however, he is whipped and beaten and the graphic nature of the violence (torturous instruments that remove chunks of flesh shown in slow-motion) may prove too much for some viewers. The film employs the use of brief flashbacks as a vehicle to cover the last supper and life-changing experiences of other important people in his life; namely disciples, his mother Mary and Mary Magdalene. This religious drama uses the original languages of the day as an attempt to add to a more timeless and authentic telling of the story. Production design and cinematography give the film a painterly feel and majestic musical score adds to the emotional intensity, particularly at times when no dialogue is spoken. Cast includes, Maia Morgenstern, Hristo Jivkov, Monica Bellucci, Rosalinda Celentano.

results.title: The Passion of Spain
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger, Grainger Maynard and Maynard
results.brief_description: As seen on ATN 7 on “The world around us”, this is a tour through Spain, looking at the diverse mix of ancient Spanish traditions and the new vibrancy which has swept through the country. Witness spectacular fairs and parades, as well as looking at the remote areas of the country, such as Galica, the Basque homelands and Gomera in the Canary Islands.

results.title: The Passion of Joan of Arc = The Passion of Jeanne D'Arc
results.creator_credit: Societe Generale Des Films and Carl Theodor Dreyer
results.brief_description: The script was based on original transcripts of the trial of Jeanne d’Arc, period detail was carefully researched, unusually solid sets were constructed and a monumental performance given by Falconetti as Jeanne. However, it is the films formal rigour which places it in the forefront of experimental film art. Cast includes Renee Falconetti, Antonin Artaud, Michel Simon.

results.title: The Passing of remoteness
results.creator_credit: Robert Hone, WGBH Productions and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The dream machine”.
Computers are continuously changing the way humans interact and have become an integral part of our lives, however, technology often comes into conflict with social systems. This program examines the way “Information Technology” has impacted on our everyday lives, raising controversial issues relating to the monitoring of individuals and their right to privacy, disruptions caused by faulty data and the catastrophic effect of software errors. Looks at Singapore’s “Information Technology Society”, France’s national computer network and the effect of “Electronic Trading” in Stock Markets. Our future is Digital but will technology control humans?

results.title: The Passing of King George VI
results.brief_description: Thousands pay homage to the memory of their beloved King George VI at Westminster Abbey. Also includes footage of funeral procession to historic Windsor, the last resting place.

results.title: The Party game
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Acquaintance Rape”.
Dramatizes the occurrence of sexual assault between teenage acquaintances through an episode involving a teenage girl and the intimate advances of her dancing partner. Points out various factors which contribute to the dancing partner’s sexual assault, and emphasises the need for young people to understand their own sexual values and those of others.

results.title: The Party's over = The Last party 2000
results.creator_credit: Camoflauge, Dakota Group, Palisades Pictures, Rebecca Chaiklin, Stanley F Buchthal and Donovan
results.brief_description: Philip Seymour Hoffman hosts an exploration of the state of politics in the United States, leading up to the 2000 election. Hoffman collects a variety of perspectives by attending a Farm Aid concert, various rallies, political conventions, a primary school, a NRA gun show, a Christian coalition, and prison towns. By interviewing the young and old, the famous and the obscure, the filmmakers strive to present a multifarious picture of America. Whilst the results are not polished, the work does capture the scandals of the election, including the faulty ballot cards, re-counts and the decision of the Supreme Court to appoint Bush. Interviews include Willie Nelson, Susan Sarandon, Noam Chomsky, and Michael Moore.
